meta.title: AI Readiness and Implementation Assessment
meta.description: Comprehensive 60-question evaluation of institutional readiness for AI integration across governance, pedagogy, technology, culture, and team dynamics

domains.name: Strategic Leadership & Vision
domains.description: Institutional commitment, leadership support, and strategic planning for AI integration

domains.name: Governance & Policy
domains.description: Policies, procedures, and governance structures for responsible AI use

domains.name: Pedagogy & Learning
domains.description: Integration of AI into teaching, learning, and curriculum development

domains.name: Technology Infrastructure
domains.description: Technical capabilities and infrastructure to support AI initiatives

domains.name: Culture & Change Management
domains.description: Organizational culture, faculty/staff readiness, and change management processes

domains.name: Team Dynamics & Collaboration
domains.description: Team collaboration, cross-functional cooperation, and collective AI adoption

questions.question: How would you characterize your institution's current AI strategy?

options.label: We have a comprehensive, board-approved AI strategy with clear goals and timelines
We are actively developing an AI strategy with stakeholder input
We have had initial discussions about AI strategy but no formal plan
Individual departments are exploring AI informally
We have not yet developed an AI strategy

questions.question: What level of leadership support exists for AI initiatives?

options.label: Strong, visible support from president/chancellor and board
Moderate support with some resource allocation
Cautious support with limited commitment
Neutral stance with no clear position
Resistance or skepticism from leadership

questions.question: What AI governance policies does your institution currently have in place?

options.label: Comprehensive AI policies covering ethics, privacy, academic integrity, and usage guidelines
Basic AI policies addressing key areas with regular updates
Draft policies under review by governance committees
Currently discussing what policies are needed
No formal AI policies in place

questions.question: How does your institution address AI ethics and responsible use?

options.label: Established ethics framework with regular training and compliance monitoring
Developing ethics framework with stakeholder input
Basic ethical guidelines for AI use
Informal discussions about AI ethics
No formal ethics framework for AI

questions.question: How is AI currently integrated into teaching and learning at your institution?

options.label: Widespread, strategic integration across multiple disciplines with faculty support
Pilot programs in select departments with positive outcomes
Individual faculty members experimenting with AI tools
Limited awareness with minimal implementation
No formal integration of AI in pedagogy

questions.question: What support exists for faculty to learn about and implement AI in their teaching?

options.label: Comprehensive professional development, resources, and ongoing support
Regular training sessions and workshops available
Occasional workshops or seminars offered
Informal peer-to-peer sharing and learning
No formal support for faculty AI learning

questions.question: How would you assess your institution's technology infrastructure for AI implementation?

options.label: Advanced infrastructure with cloud computing, high-performance systems, and AI-ready platforms
Adequate infrastructure with some cloud services and modern systems
Basic infrastructure that could support simple AI applications
Limited infrastructure requiring significant upgrades
Inadequate infrastructure for AI implementation

questions.question: What AI tools and platforms are currently available to your campus community?

options.label: Enterprise AI platforms with institutional licenses and support
Selected AI tools available to faculty and students
Pilot implementation of specific AI tools
Individual users accessing AI tools independently
No institutional AI tools available

questions.question: How receptive is your campus culture to AI adoption?

options.label: Highly receptive with enthusiasm and proactive adoption
Moderately receptive with growing interest
Cautiously open with some concerns
Resistant with significant concerns and skepticism
Highly resistant with strong opposition

questions.question: How does your institution approach change management for technology initiatives?

options.label: Systematic change management with clear communication and support
Structured process with stakeholder engagement
Informal process with some planning
Ad hoc approach with limited planning
No formal change management process

questions.question: How does your AI strategy align with your institution's Quality Enhancement Plan (QEP) or strategic initiatives?

options.label: AI strategy is fully integrated with QEP and strategic planning processes
Some alignment with broader strategic initiatives
Informal connections to institutional priorities
AI is treated as a separate, standalone initiative
No consideration of alignment with institutional strategy

questions.question: What budget allocation exists for AI initiatives?

options.label: Dedicated multi-year budget with clear allocation across departments
Annual budget allocation for AI projects
Project-by-project funding approval
Individual departments funding AI from existing budgets
No specific budget allocation for AI initiatives

questions.question: How are AI success metrics and KPIs defined at your institution?

options.label: Comprehensive KPIs across student success, efficiency, and innovation
Basic metrics for usage and adoption
Metrics defined for pilot programs only
Informal tracking of outcomes
No defined success metrics for AI initiatives

questions.question: How does your institution handle data privacy and security for AI applications?

options.label: Comprehensive data governance framework with AI-specific protocols
Existing data policies adapted for AI use cases
Basic guidelines for AI data handling
Relying on general institutional data policies
No specific data governance for AI

questions.question: What governance structure oversees AI initiatives?

options.label: Dedicated AI governance committee with cross-functional representation
Existing IT or academic committee with AI oversight
Informal working group or task force
Individual administrator or department oversight
No formal governance structure for AI

questions.question: How are academic integrity concerns addressed with AI tools?

options.label: Comprehensive academic integrity policy updated for AI era
Updated guidelines addressing AI in academic work
Faculty have discretion with some institutional guidance
Informal discussion without formal policy updates
No updates to academic integrity policies for AI

questions.question: How is AI being used to enhance student advising and support services?

options.label: AI integrated into advising systems with predictive analytics
Pilot programs using AI for student support
Exploring AI options for advising enhancement
Limited awareness of AI potential in advising
No implementation of AI in student services

questions.question: What AI tools are being used for curriculum development and assessment?

options.label: AI integrated into curriculum mapping, assessment design, and learning analytics
AI used selectively for specific curriculum or assessment tasks
Experimental use by individual faculty or departments
Considering AI options for curriculum work
No use of AI in curriculum development or assessment

questions.question: How are learning outcomes and student success being measured with AI integration?

options.label: Comprehensive learning analytics with AI-driven insights
Basic tracking of AI impact on student performance
Measurement in pilot programs only
Relying on anecdotal evidence of impact
No systematic measurement of AI impact on learning

questions.question: What is your institution's approach to AI vendor evaluation and selection?

options.label: Systematic vendor evaluation with security, pedagogy, and integration criteria
Structured review process with multiple stakeholders
Basic evaluation focusing on cost and features
Ad hoc selection by individual departments
No formal vendor evaluation process

questions.question: How robust is your data infrastructure for AI analytics and insights?

options.label: Advanced data warehouse with integrated systems and real-time analytics
Adequate infrastructure with some integrated data sources
Basic infrastructure with siloed data systems
Limited infrastructure requiring significant integration work
Inadequate infrastructure for meaningful AI analytics

questions.question: What level of IT support exists for AI implementation and maintenance?

options.label: Dedicated AI/ML team with specialized expertise
IT staff trained in AI technologies and support
IT staff learning AI technologies as needed
Relying primarily on external vendor support
No specialized support for AI technologies

questions.question: How is faculty development around AI being approached?

options.label: Comprehensive faculty development program with ongoing support
Regular professional development opportunities available
Occasional workshops or conference attendance
Faculty pursuing AI learning on individual initiative
No formal faculty development around AI

questions.question: What is the student response to AI integration in their learning experience?

options.label: Enthusiastic adoption with students requesting more AI integration
Generally positive response with growing comfort
Mixed response with varying levels of comfort
Cautious acceptance with some resistance
Significant resistance or concerns from students

questions.question: How does your institution communicate about AI initiatives to stakeholders?

options.label: Comprehensive communication strategy across all stakeholder groups
Regular updates through multiple channels
Periodic communication about major AI initiatives
Limited communication, primarily to internal stakeholders
No formal communication strategy for AI initiatives

maturity_levels.name: Initial/Ad Hoc
maturity_levels.description: Limited awareness and informal approaches to AI

maturity_levels.name: Developing
maturity_levels.description: Growing awareness with some planning and pilot efforts

maturity_levels.name: Defined
maturity_levels.description: Structured approach with documented processes and support

maturity_levels.name: Managed
maturity_levels.description: Well-managed AI initiatives with institutional support

maturity_levels.name: Optimized
maturity_levels.description: Comprehensive, strategic AI integration across the institution
